723588f-a.folder: Union Square & [17th Street (East)] & [Union Square Park.], Manhattan, NY
723588f-a.text:
Union Square: The recently constructed stand on the northerly margin of this open area. This, technically is the south side of East 17th Street, between Union Square East and Union Square West. The photographer is viewing southward to show across the roof of same, an office building at the S.W. corner of E. 14th Street and Broadway.

May 8, 1938
F.L. Sperr
723588f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square - [17th Street (East)] - [Union Square Park.]

723621f-a.text:
THE NEW HOME OF THE SOCIETY OF TAMMANY

Now being erected on Union Square, New York City, not far from the Hall of Fourteenth Street which has been Tammany's headquarters for sixty years

Photograph by Wide World Photos
August 1928
723621f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

723623f-a.text:
The new Tammany Hall, Union Square East at the S.E. corner of 17th Street, newly erected on the site of the old Westmoreland Apartments (originally Hotel), which occupied the site from about 1877 to 1928. The bank is about to move into the ground floor. In the background may be seen the tower of the new Consolidated Gas and New York Edison Building, recently completed on 14th Street on the site of the old Tammany Hall and the Academy of Music. The Society of St. Tammany, or Columbian Order, was founded in Philadelphia and spread through New England, before a New York City chapter was established in 1789. It was originally a benevolent organization, and first identified itself with politics in the presidential campaign of 1800, when, under the leadership of Vice Presidential candidate Aaron Burr, it supported the Jefferson-Burr ticket. The first Tammany Hall, built in 1801, stood on Frankfort and Nassau Streets. On July 4, 1868, the second Hall on 14th Street was opened with the Democratic National Convention of that year. In 1928 it moved into the present building.
The Tammany Hall General Committee, with which it is practically identical in membership, has for a long time been in control of the Democratic Party in New York County, at times almost to the point of complete identification with it. This picture, for instance, is taken near the height of Mayor James J. Walker's popularity, the spring preceding his re-election. Tammany Hall is not only identified with the Party in Manhattan, but is working harmoniously with the leaders of the other four boroughs.
May, 1929.
723623f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

723624f-a.text:
Tammany Hall, Union Square East at S.E. corner of 17th Street, the ground floor occupied by a branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company. The new Tammany Hall is four years old, as pictured here. At the time it was built, the store of 42 Union Square, adjoining, was occupied by Flaxman Woolen,
Incorporated.
March 25, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, Election Day of that year, when, for the first time in twenty years, the Tammany candidates for Mayor, Comptroller, and Aldermanic President were all defeated. But the Borough President and four candidates for County Offices, whose names
follow the first three, were elected.
The building in the background, with the "Hyman -- Human -- " sign is not shown in this view because of the angle of the camera.
November 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
723624f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

723624f-b.text:
Tammany Hall, Union Square East at S.E. corner of 17th Street, the ground floor occupied by a branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company. The new Tammany Hall is four years old, as pictured here. At the time it was built, the store of 42 Union Square, adjoining, was occupied by Flaxman Woolen,
Incorporated.
March 25, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, Election Day of that year, when, for the first time in twenty years, the Tammany candidates for Mayor, Comptroller, and Aldermanic President were all defeated. But the Borough President and four candidates for County Offices, whose names
follow the first three, were elected.
The building in the background, with the "Hyman -- Human -- " sign is not shown in this view because of the angle of the camera.
November 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
723624f-b.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

723625f-a.text:
Union Square East (Fourth Avenue), at the S. E. corner of East 17th Street (left), showing the building housing the Columbian Order, better known as Tammany Hall.
1940
George D. Chinn
723625f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

723626f-a.text:
Union Square East (normally 4th Avenue) at E. 17th Street as photographed northeastward from variods points. No. 1 is from the diagonal far corner of the Square, at Broadway and 14th Street; No. 2 from atop an office structure on the same street and No. 3 from inside the Park. Occupying the various corners at this point are, the Everett Building, the Guardian Life Insurance Co. Building and Tammany Hall. Incidentally, Fourth Avenue, officially starts there and that portion bordering the Square
is identified by same.
The Lincoln statue appears in the earlier view. This is at the Broadway point, popularly known as "Death Curve." This arose from the danger to pedestrians from the speeding Broadway streetcars on their turn into 14th Street
from Union Square West.
View 11 February 12, 1928 Neg N. 221
View 2: August 4, 1930 Neg A. 1i
View 3: February 24, 1933
P. L. Sperr
723626f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

731153f-a.folder: 17th Street and Union Square, Manhattan, N.Y.
731153f-a.text:
Military Parade upon the occasion of Columbus Day, October 12th., 1892. A Connecticut Inf. Regiment is shown making a left column turn from Union
Square East, into 17th., Street.
October 12, 1892.
731153f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Columbus Day.

731184f-a.folder: 17th Street and Union Square East, Manhattan, N.Y.
731184f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Decoration Day Parade.
